document.title: California Common Core State Standards: English Language Arts and Literacy

C165A64C9E494FC38F72EBF73EC4B103.description: Acquire and use accurately general academic and domain-specific words and phrases, sufficient for reading, writing, speaking, and listening at the college and career readiness level; demonstrate independence in gathering vocabulary knowledge when considering a word or phrase important to comprehension or expression.

DF1322171B1945F2934AC1E06EBC62F6.description: Analyze nuances in the meaning of words with similar denotations.

61C82EE24DFB4E3D96FE8D39A1E657A2.description: Interpret figures of speech (e.g., hyperbole, paradox) in context and analyze their role in the text.

9377DAEFD6B548489AC4E274D0C2D89B.description: Demonstrate understanding of figurative language, word relationships, and nuances in word meanings.

BC31635F4B3A445AAD09D58B051B6E8F.description: Verify the preliminary determination of the meaning of a word or phrase (e.g., by checking the inferred meaning in context or in a dictionary).

9ECDA947CA634F95B9841D496EA9D021.description: Consult general and specialized reference materials (e.g., college-level dictionaries, rhyming dictionaries, bilingual dictionaries, glossaries, thesauruses), both print and digital, to find the pronunciation of a word or determine or clarify its precise meaning, its part of speech, its etymology, or its standard usage.

E4709585A7854D3BA5A8803B59F32D62.description: Identify and correctly use patterns of word changes that indicate different meanings or parts of speech (e.g., conceive, conception, conceivable). Apply knowledge of Greek, Latin, and Anglo-Saxon roots and affixes to draw inferences concerning the meaning of scientific and mathematical terminology.

B954CFA8531241D3B9DE25BDAD8332B1.description: Use context (e.g., the overall meaning of a sentence, paragraph, or text; a word's position or function in a sentence) as a clue to the meaning of a word or phrase.

B1B27C6A2E9044AA9C3670B21CE021C8.description: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grades 11—12 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.

FF787C713BF74FC0B9640490EF0303B3.description: Vary syntax for effect, consulting references (e.g., Tufte's Artful Sentences) for guidance as needed; apply an understanding of syntax to the study of complex texts when reading.

72FD3F379A3F439F85F866ECEF1B571A.description: Apply knowledge of language to understand how language functions in different contexts, to make effective choices for meaning or style, and to comprehend more fully when reading or listening.

A4A1903C9F2A46E6AD9BA5B7F63F14BC.description: Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English capitalization, punctuation, and spelling when writing.

FB9E59798AF94AB0B7F95286728085F1.description: Resolve issues of complex or contested usage, consulting references (e.g., Merriam-Webster's Dictionary of English Usage, Garner's Modern American Usage) as needed.

B13A81D626FC4C0E9720F6C898A9BCEF.description: Apply the understanding that usage is a matter of convention, can change over time, and is sometimes contested.

D745FD66CD8749B88E0636C296138836.description: Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English grammar and usage when writing or speaking.

27AFBD102A3A42BBBE9505B78909EA80.description: Acquire and use accurately a range of general academic and domain-specific words and phrases sufficient for reading, writing, speaking, and listening at the college and career readiness level; demonstrate independence in gathering vocabulary knowledge when considering a word or phrase important to comprehension or expression.

C64CB105B0424B2AA61EBF8245EF8D76.description: Acquire and use accurately a range of general academic and domain-specific words and phrases sufficient for reading, writing, speaking, and listening at the college and career readiness level; demonstrate independence in gathering vocabulary knowledge when encountering an unknown term important to comprehension or expression.

C0E821C19E8844BCA60B1F49764CAE5B.description: Demonstrate understanding of figurative language, word relationships, and nuances in word meanings.

CFC1817D88FA4AE1A8449352EC140485.description: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases by using context clues, analyzing meaningful word parts, and consulting general and specialized reference materials, as appropriate.

B5DF6E541CF44E6EAC7694EC5069B65E.description: Apply knowledge of language to understand how language functions in different contexts, to make effective choices for meaning or style, and to comprehend more fully when reading or listening.

5BB9DFCD1DF2451EA2704519739781F4.description: Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English capitalization, punctuation, and spelling when writing.

57AF628F70074080A145062420BB2F80.description: Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English grammar and usage when writing or speaking.

96CD6CA9B0F7487ABDF9F6C4500C57B3.description: College and Career Readiness Anchor Standards for Language

271BF5D13FE44FE3B9C02FB4E9A07E8A.description: Adapt speech to a variety of contexts and tasks, demonstrating command of formal English when indicated or appropriate.

33FED9946B4E47CD84FB1ABA74E530EA.description: Make strategic use of digital media (e.g., textual, graphical, audio, visual, and interactive elements) in presentations to enhance understanding of findings, reasoning, and evidence and to add interest.

73822F48ADB544FAB41CB7E45A32544F.description: Plan and present an argument that: supports a precise claim; provides a logical sequence for claims, counterclaims, and evidence; uses rhetorical devices to support assertions (e.g., analogy, appeal to logic through reasoning, appeal to emotion or ethical belief); uses varied syntax to link major sections of the presentation to create cohesion and clarity; and provides a concluding statement that supports the argument presented. (11th or 12th grade)

9B77503E19AA450CB8B781F772DD18D1.description: Plan and deliver a reflective narrative that: explores the significance of a personal experience, event, or concern; uses sensory language to convey a vivid picture; includes appropriate narrative techniques (e.g., dialogue, pacing, description); and draws comparisons between the specific incident and broader themes. (11th or 12th grade)

B7A1732DD0AD4DD6BA13BEFCFDD25087.description: Present information, findings, and supporting evidence (e.g., reflective, historical investigation, response to literature presentations), conveying a clear and distinct perspective and a logical argument, such that listeners can follow the line of reasoning, alternative or opposing perspectives are addressed, and the organization, development, substance, and style are appropriate to purpose, audience, and a range of formal and informal tasks. Use appropriate eye contact, adequate volume, and clear pronunciation.

7146135EE2FD4986A1144728DAEF4AE9.description: Evaluate a speaker's point of view, reasoning, and use of evidence and rhetoric, assessing the stance, premises, links among ideas, word choice, points of emphasis, and tone used.

7583DB2CA489426B8B1F397BBF0C45A1.description: Integrate multiple sources of information presented in diverse formats and media (e.g., visually, quantitatively, orally) in order to make informed decisions and solve problems, evaluating the credibility and accuracy of each source and noting any discrepancies among the data.

A9D98326F4EE4C3C9619D598EF62535E.description: Respond thoughtfully to diverse perspectives; synthesize comments, claims, and evidence made on all sides of an issue; resolve contradictions when possible; and determine what additional information or research is required to deepen the investigation or complete the task.

14A6524213F34BB69A8BFAB38B48D8C2.description: Propel conversations by posing and responding to questions that probe reasoning and evidence; ensure a hearing for a full range of positions on a topic or issue; clarify, verify, or challenge ideas and conclusions; and promote divergent and creative perspectives.

97B8088F0F1D437396A903BD209231D1.description: Work with peers to promote civil, democratic discussions and decision-making, set clear goals and deadlines, and establish individual roles as needed.

87541C08CD0B49068F1801E09E329AF2.description: Come to discussions prepared, having read and researched material under study; explicitly draw on that preparation by referring to evidence from texts and other research on the topic or issue to stimulate a thoughtful, well-reasoned exchange of ideas.

A614456488B34CF0A75A6AA5391ECDDF.description: Initiate and participate effectively in a range of collaborative discussions (one-on-one, in groups, and teacher-led) with diverse partners on grades 11—12 topics, texts, and issues, building on others' ideas and expressing their own clearly and persuasively.

4A758CE9921F4F6DA3F7CE396D372DA0.description: Adapt speech to a variety of contexts and communicative tasks, demonstrating command of formal English when indicated or appropriate.

BE7BCB47C1A8431DB7CA9C93E523182C.description: Make strategic use of digital media and visual displays of data to express information and enhance understanding of presentations.

0B84DA73EF7C4FCE80B83A761EFB48B2.description: Present information, findings, and supporting evidence such that listeners can follow the line of reasoning and the organization, development, and style are appropriate to task, purpose, and audience.

93E9E1FE958F425C9FFE450DEF8DF217.description: Evaluate a speaker's point of view, reasoning, and use of evidence and rhetoric.

D78DAAEBE0644D21A10F0E099D1510B7.description: Integrate and evaluate information presented in diverse media and formats, including visually, quantitatively, and orally.

72BF6068009B402986976668756CEE33.description: Prepare for and participate effectively in a range of conversations and collaborations with diverse partners, building on others' ideas and expressing their own clearly and persuasively.

96ACC2CC69894E1A8C8114CA5838AC82.description: College and Career Readiness Anchor Standards for Speaking and Listening

36A929D2783D4A3592B980E7B3A43C7A.description: Write routinely over extended time frames (time for reflection and revision) and shorter time frames (a single sitting or a day or two) for a range of discipline-specific tasks, purposes, and audiences.

4825C16511D24D6682F95C430A9FED86.description: Draw evidence from informational texts to support analysis, reflection, and research.

38B8A911ED3D461892B6FFB7B975F27E.description: Gather relevant information from multiple authoritative print and digital sources, using advanced searches effectively; assess the strengths and limitations of each source in terms of the specific task, purpose, and audience; integrate information into the text selectively to maintain the flow of ideas, avoiding plagiarism and over-reliance on any one source and following a standard format for citation.

5A4E58FE1FF04013BCBD168C28198AF0.description: Conduct short as well as more sustained research projects to answer a question (including a self-generated question) or solve a problem; narrow or broaden the inquiry when appropriate; synthesize multiple sources on the subject, demonstrating understanding of the subject under investigation.

41B13E9FF8E44068A5B03BA791CDE03E.description: Research to Build and Present Knowledge

550B514A88254E8EA477309C86428428.description: Use technology, including the Internet, to produce, publish, and update individual or shared writing products in response to ongoing feedback, including new arguments or information.

D9477A71DB444DA4A12F2E73E294B6A6.description: Develop and strengthen writing as needed by planning, revising, editing, rewriting, or trying a new approach, focusing on addressing what is most significant for a specific purpose and audience.

800B661E16A340A7ACB74777944EF339.description: Produce clear and coherent writing in which the development, organization, and style are appropriate to task, purpose, and audience.

696A900BC34B47EAB6DA1F9C2F87BFD7.description: Provide a concluding statement or section that follows from and supports the information or explanation provided (e.g., articulating implications or the significance of the topic).

D7101EC7250A40AD9EA67386FE690C9E.description: Use precise language, domain-specific vocabulary and techniques such as metaphor, simile, and analogy to manage the complexity of the topic; convey a knowledgeable stance in a style that responds to the discipline and context as well as to the expertise of likely readers.

F1C095096B7F4D1DBCC2C20732D9F723.description: Use varied transitions and sentence structures to link the major sections of the text, create cohesion, and clarify the relationships among complex ideas and concepts.

881F3857582B4C979D8317A0A1F938F5.description: Develop the topic thoroughly by selecting the most significant and relevant facts, extended definitions, concrete details, quotations, or other information and examples appropriate to the audience's knowledge of the topic.

B5F9410DEA5A459F817DCD506B888D07.description: Introduce a topic and organize complex ideas, concepts, and information so that each new element builds on that which precedes it to create a unified whole; include formatting (e.g., headings), graphics (e.g., figures, tables), and multimedia when useful to aiding comprehension.

5E55218DD20E43CB85CD245102762F99.description: Write informative/explanatory texts, including the narration of historical events, scientific procedures/ experiments, or technical processes.

7295D2FA7ABB4672A6C5556ECAB1D6DC.description: Provide a concluding statement or section that follows from or supports the argument presented.

7B56124D829447339B1B570F61BCBADC.description: Establish and maintain a formal style and objective tone while attending to the norms and conventions of the discipline in which they are writing.

E45E119AB7924192906583B5EF59F553.description: Use words, phrases, and clauses as well as varied syntax to link the major sections of the text, create cohesion, and clarify the relationships between claim(s) and reasons, between reasons and evidence, and between claim(s) and counterclaims.

BCFCC2C1E7414F33AF039154BBC7112E.description: Develop claim(s) and counterclaims fairly and thoroughly, supplying the most relevant data and evidence for each while pointing out the strengths and limitations of both claim(s) and counterclaims in a discipline-appropriate form that anticipates the audience's knowledge level, concerns, values, and possible biases.

BFF4A3D79C524C64B73CBB041E3054B9.description: Introduce precise, knowledgeable claim(s), establish the significance of the claim(s), distinguish the claim(s) from alternate or opposing claims, and create an organization that logically sequences the claim(s), counterclaims, reasons, and evidence.

318610E2246441C3ABA689224605E54D.description: Write arguments focused on discipline-specific content.

9F24CA966A8246B89729C8CD5994080A.description: Writing Standards for Literacy in History/Social Studies, Science, and Technical Subjects 6—12

5900D498088E4E79B51A9DB8F0BD35E3.description: Write routinely over extended time frames (time for research, reflection, and revision) and shorter time frames (a single sitting or a day or two) for a range of discipline-specific tasks, purposes, and audiences.

B57C15FE0D7C4323AE8897F81D4F6614.description: Apply grades 11—12 Reading standards to literary nonfiction (e.g., "Delineate and evaluate the reasoning in seminal U.S. texts, including the application of constitutional principles and use of legal reasoning [e.g., in U.S. Supreme Court Case majority opinions and dissents] and the premises, purposes, and arguments in works of public advocacy [e.g., The Federalist, presidential addresses]").

75897144CB5D47139354ED67DA3C4B01.description: Apply grades 11—12 Reading standards to literature (e.g., "Demonstrate knowledge of eighteenth-, nineteenth- and early-twentieth-century foundational works of American literature, including how two or more texts from the same period treat similar themes or topics").

483C3DBBABAC47A7B56F332BCFB3A05B.description: Draw evidence from literary or informational texts to support analysis, reflection, and research.

5D7734B2DB0942D298A8CB2454A33AFD.description: Gather relevant information from multiple authoritative print and digital sources, using advanced searches effectively; assess the strengths and limitations of each source in terms of the task, purpose, and audience; integrate information into the text selectively to maintain the flow of ideas, avoiding plagiarism and over-reliance on any one source and following a standard format for citation including footnotes and endnotes.

1CE9890F9F2948FF8E331A1E9A5E79D6.description: Conduct short as well as more sustained research projects to answer a question (including a self-generated question) or solve a problem; narrow or broaden the inquiry when appropriate; synthesize multiple sources on the subject, demonstrating understanding of the subject under investigation.

816F0426CB1343D29DC8DF61BCD981B4.description: Research to Build and Present Knowledge

C518231AD8464CBC859185B583B7E21A.description: Use technology, including the Internet, to produce, publish, and update individual or shared writing products in response to ongoing feedback, including new arguments or information.

E3B2C1073219464A8997B71F0066635E.description: Develop and strengthen writing as needed by planning, revising, editing, rewriting, or trying a new approach, focusing on addressing what is most significant for a specific purpose and audience.

A91EE95F9314445C8708DDDAD26AE6C7.description: Produce clear and coherent writing in which the development, organization, and style are appropriate to task, purpose, and audience.

047F4271C0544E4CB1B47118DECE1A29.description: Provide a conclusion that follows from and reflects on what is experienced, observed, or resolved over the course of the narrative.

93B2CE4192114D8083CDBFE492DEAE55.description: Use precise words and phrases, telling details, and sensory language to convey a vivid picture of the experiences, events, setting, and/or characters.

26891D6F6CB44E6DB7A4036439444DEC.description: Use a variety of techniques to sequence events so that they build on one another to create a coherent whole and build toward a particular tone and outcome (e.g., a sense of mystery, suspense, growth, or resolution).

87DD8C16EF244513B06214CBD8FA7397.description: Use narrative techniques, such as dialogue, pacing, description, reflection, and multiple plot lines, to develop experiences, events, and/or characters.

012D64BF8AB84ECC8FE9867D2334FCEC.description: Engage and orient the reader by setting out a problem, situation, or observation and its significance, establishing one or multiple point(s) of view, and introducing a narrator and/or characters; create a smooth progression of experiences or events.

C6151C6B0E5745D4BEE9B67878386627.description: Write narratives to develop real or imagined experiences or events using effective technique, well-chosen details, and well-structured event sequences.

C7CC8B6A6107486787E505D94FB5E1E3.description: Provide a concluding statement or section that follows from and supports the information or explanation presented (e.g., articulating implications or the significance of the topic).

05E1AEBA8E0E4EF68A71A11770E4517D.description: Establish and maintain a formal style and objective tone while attending to the norms and conventions of the discipline in which they are writing.

8FA332618CF54B2E9CB6822EECB631B0.description: Use precise language, domain-specific vocabulary, and techniques such as metaphor, simile, and analogy to manage the complexity of the topic.

E0B2C51259594D1AB122DB9F044F3B56.description: Use appropriate and varied transitions and syntax to link the major sections of the text, create cohesion, and clarify the relationships among complex ideas and concepts.

41DCF4AC0A354F549AD430BE7BDCF423.description: Develop the topic thoroughly by selecting the most significant and relevant facts, extended definitions, concrete details, quotations, or other information and examples appropriate to the audience's knowledge of the topic.

1D823501C89747EFB9C51F1A266E6156.description: Introduce a topic or thesis statement; organize complex ideas, concepts, and information so that each new element builds on that which precedes it to create a unified whole; include formatting (e.g., headings), graphics (e.g., figures, tables), and multimedia when useful to aiding comprehension.

966924449FAA423AA9D77BAAA4C95D75.description: Write informative/explanatory texts to examine and convey complex ideas, concepts, and information clearly and accurately through the effective selection, organization, and analysis of content.

A32CE74444BF47F486EDEB5C0D22E0D2.description: Use specific rhetorical devices to support assertions (e.g., appeal to logic through reasoning; appeal to emotion or ethical belief; relate a personal anecdote, case study, or analogy).

21D0B1BF96F4421B86F853BF7EAD9163.description: Provide a concluding statement or section that follows from and supports the argument presented.

0CA1E3E4EAE9481D89D5249117A15030.description: Establish and maintain a formal style and objective tone while attending to the norms and conventions of the discipline in which they are writing.

C6409C693D694D2ABCE70562184E70D1.description: Use words, phrases, and clauses as well as varied syntax to link the major sections of the text, create cohesion, and clarify the relationships between claim(s) and reasons, between reasons and evidence, and between claim(s) and counterclaims.

3C35B9311FDB4821B12E74E77CAF79C5.description: Develop claim(s) and counterclaims fairly and thoroughly, supplying the most relevant evidence for each while pointing out the strengths and limitations of both in a manner that anticipates the audience's knowledge level, concerns, values, and possible biases.

71F0C5D94381444990EF11D48311AC6B.description: Introduce precise, knowledgeable claim(s), establish the significance of the claim(s), distinguish the claim(s) from alternate or opposing claims, and create an organization that logically sequences claim(s), counterclaims, reasons, and evidence.

D4DE5F8B438B49BE945AC7CBE24C6A08.description: Write arguments to support claims in an analysis of substantive topics or texts, using valid reasoning and relevant and sufficient evidence.

6DF76BCF126B4E3DBBA7A8F60D0EAA30.description: Write routinely over extended time frames (time for research, reflection, and revision) and shorter time frames (a single sitting or a day or two) for a range of tasks, purposes, and audiences.

C760836622FF411787443D12B47CBBDE.description: Draw evidence from literary or informational texts to support analysis, reflection, and research.

594AFCE9D9E64DC885B18EA678F09BCF.description: Gather relevant information from multiple print and digital sources, assess the credibility and accuracy of each source, and integrate the information while avoiding plagiarism.

5E8B3B8E217048E78CAC4EB8F6F9BA6C.description: Conduct short as well as more sustained research projects based on focused questions, demonstrating understanding of the subject under investigation.

699CB5F0F7B240EAA101031C7E5A2549.description: Research to Build and Present Knowledge

EFE374DA1C2F410A86A5314750C84D27.description: Use technology, including the Internet, to produce and publish writing and to interact and collaborate with others.

4DDB3D4B6CD14299B1707B7350B4AEB2.description: Develop and strengthen writing as needed by planning, revising, editing, rewriting, or trying a new approach.

B88EED1B71054C34827E197956A00030.description: Produce clear and coherent writing in which the development, organization, and style are appropriate to task, purpose, and audience.

CF5EF6564D924F9C815B895CF33D3B77.description: Write narratives to develop real or imagined experiences or events using effective technique, well-chosen details, and well-structured event sequences.

3E9D7EEE28F44C0AACDCE94F05D5E278.description: Write informative/explanatory texts to examine and convey complex ideas and information clearly and accurately through the effective selection, organization, and analysis of content.

B6BE2FC9DF92415D94DC81FC8749C454.description: Write arguments to support claims in an analysis of substantive topics or texts, using valid reasoning and relevant and sufficient evidence.

E55DBA20ABA14C868F74FA5D022EDED1.description: College and Career Readiness Anchor Standards for Writing

DED517B49592490FAF812AA70A4C0235.description: By the end of grade 12, read and comprehend science/technical texts in the grades 11—CCR text complexity band independently and proficiently.

669A565C6C484D029ACC595F5B0CC601.description: Range of Reading and Level of Text Complexity

98B86A1BE92E46239DFBE4E0918CDAFD.description: Synthesize information from a range of sources (e.g., texts, experiments, simulations) into a coherent understanding of a process, phenomenon, or concept, resolving conflicting information when possible.

960CBACA6DA746B4B05148699BFDD85E.description: Evaluate the hypotheses, data, analysis, and conclusions in a science or technical text, verifying the data when possible and corroborating or challenging conclusions with other sources of information.

5DD26218DE8C44CD8E34EE17D6FF0932.description: Integrate and evaluate multiple sources of information presented in diverse formats and media (e.g., quantitative data, video, multimedia) in order to address a question or solve a problem.

A55BABEF25774AE2ACCF67CC3E4611F7.description: Analyze the author's purpose in providing an explanation, describing a procedure, or discussing an experiment in a text, identifying important issues that remain unresolved.

5DA9547109FA4F80A03A7F1CE5335300.description: Analyze how the text structures information or ideas into categories or hierarchies, demonstrating understanding of the information or ideas.

4EFE8D9D78DB461EB2C3548A08D18BA4.description: Determine the meaning of symbols, key terms, and other domain-specific words and phrases as they are used in a specific scientific or technical context relevant to grades 11—12 texts and topics.

840C4BC6EFB04B8F942232F6727026F0.description: Follow precisely a complex multistep procedure when carrying out experiments, taking measurements, or performing technical tasks; analyze the specific results based on explanations in the text.

62ACD79004464FDC98F99DBFCCCBCEB9.description: Determine the central ideas or conclusions of a text; summarize complex concepts, processes, or information presented in a text by paraphrasing them in simpler but still accurate terms.

97BFCDF364974B6EB71DA9B78AA850C2.description: Cite specific textual evidence to support analysis of science and technical texts, attending to important distinctions the author makes and to any gaps or inconsistencies in the account.

7A19A2FDE9FF4D8C92F069E6BD2357C0.description: Reading Standards for Literacy in Science and Technical Subjects 6—12

38C2F8EC3D984C02B56CA511F876481E.description: By the end of grade 12, read and comprehend history/social studies texts in the grades 11—CCR text complexity band independently and proficiently.

E3167D8BFD2F4590A639CED8BD798C2D.description: Range of Reading and Level of Text Complexity

D41219F1BA764E82ABB59327AD5FCEDA.description: Integrate information from diverse sources, both primary and secondary, into a coherent understanding of an idea or event, noting discrepancies among sources.

5CBE3D4A706E4E429CABC072199DF1DA.description: Evaluate an author's premises, claims, and evidence by corroborating or challenging them with other information.

E093CF1C83C842E1B327DC4D1A2ED60F.description: Integrate and evaluate multiple sources of information presented in diverse formats and media (e.g., visually, quantitatively, as well as in words) in order to address a question or solve a problem.

289E59D6AF024EB3BDE30A5BBA1E5592.description: Evaluate authors' differing points of view on the same historical event or issue by assessing the authors' claims, reasoning, and evidence.

EEB6E1E45EEE43059596878619A9D15A.description: Analyze in detail how a complex primary source is structured, including how key sentences, paragraphs, and larger portions of the text contribute to the whole.

FD56DD805B1348C286A3BC5FBB1685F4.description: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including analyzing how an author uses and refines the meaning of a key term over the course of a text (e.g., how Madison defines faction in Federalist No. 10).

A0C629BF82124E74A358E73C3500039D.description: Evaluate various explanations for actions or events and determine which explanation best accords with textual evidence, acknowledging where the text leaves matters uncertain.

0D6B151EA96B4E8CA21452E13548623D.description: Determine the central ideas or information of a primary or secondary source; provide an accurate summary that makes clear the relationships among the key details and ideas.

DB9B65044CDC4C22BC52B3D709451643.description: Cite specific textual evidence to support analysis of primary and secondary sources, connecting insights gained from specific details to an understanding of the text as a whole.

28DF03F8F6884B52944519866AC47BE3.description: Reading Standards for Literacy in History/Social Studies 6—12

FC92A3768F5B4F939BB0013D20C29AE3.description:
By the end of grade 11, read and comprehend literary nonfiction in the grades 11—CCR text complexity band proficiently, with scaffolding as needed at the high end of the range.
By the end of grade 12, read and comprehend literary nonfiction at the high end of the grades 11—CCR text complexity band independently and proficiently.

B23482945CB649EEBEC4F2259FCE177A.description: Range of Reading and Level of Text Complexity

2B4CD4C71B5D4E908CAA8D456BDFCFBA.description: Analyze seventeenth-, eighteenth-, and nineteenth-century foundational U.S. documents of historical and literary significance (including The Declaration of Independence, the Preamble to the Constitution, the Bill of Rights, and Lincoln's Second Inaugural Address) for their themes, purposes, and rhetorical features.

CC4D784537B342FDB8CD74877D40775B.description: Delineate and evaluate the reasoning in seminal U.S. texts, including the application of constitutional principles and use of legal reasoning (e.g., in U.S. Supreme Court majority opinions and dissents) and the premises, purposes, and arguments in works of public advocacy (e.g., The Federalist, presidential addresses).

7C9B536E5F3141198802E4A7B8462EE7.description: Integrate and evaluate multiple sources of information presented in different media or formats (e.g., visually, quantitatively) as well as in words in order to address a question or solve a problem.

E4FAA98BC7C0407EB566FBCD9BF5B6DA.description: Determine an author's point of view or purpose in a text in which the rhetoric is particularly effective, analyzing how style and content contribute to the power, persuasiveness, or beauty of the text.

D2B7CE76C5654A97A9553AAA03AB82F2.description: Analyze the use of text features (e.g., graphics, headers, captions) in public documents.

40ACE14001204D5F8F1C7B72220366B0.description: Analyze and evaluate the effectiveness of the structure an author uses in his or her exposition or argument, including whether the structure makes points clear, convincing, and engaging.

75B610E4FCF544A0BDBA67C2D155000E.description: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative, connotative, and technical meanings; analyze how an author uses and refines the meaning of a key term or terms over the course of a text (e.g., how Madison defines faction in Federalist No. 10). (See grade 11–12 Language standards 4–6 for additional expectations.)

5C196DCFC4054E5AAE5C542C0F8EFE4D.description: Analyze a complex set of ideas or sequence of events and explain how specific individuals, ideas, or events interact and develop over the course of the text.

3F0A9B4310B447099D863D0C7E59E6F4.description: Determine two or more central ideas of a text and analyze their development over the course of the text, including how they interact and build on one another to provide a complex analysis; provide an objective summary of the text.

04114AF98A18462E8493E98B410C4FCC.description: Cite strong and thorough textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text, including determining where the text leaves matters uncertain.

8D664094FB404BCCBA6AD3806D8E35F1.description:
By the end of grade 11, read and comprehend literature, including stories, dramas, and poems, in the grades 11—CCR text complexity band proficiently, with scaffolding as needed at the high end of the range.
By the end of grade 12, read and comprehend literature, including stories, dramas, and poems, at the high end of the grades 11—CCR text complexity band independently and proficiently.

DE2C06035F3247DC99609C3EAB9097C2.description: Range of Reading and Level of Text Complexity

8FBD9884BCB34BFBA61B4502F8D62F08.description: Demonstrate knowledge of eighteenth-, nineteenth- and early-twentieth-century foundational works of American literature, including how two or more texts from the same period treat similar themes or topics.

A7EC3110A59341DBB3DC927D5BFAB69C.description: Analyze multiple interpretations of a story, drama, or poem (e.g., recorded or live production of a play or recorded novel or poetry), evaluating how each version interprets the source text. (Include at least one play by Shakespeare and one play by an American dramatist.)

85F33E7ACC58461DADDDBADF1D240EAC.description: Analyze a case in which grasping point of view requires distinguishing what is directly stated in a text from what is really meant (e.g., satire, sarcasm, irony, or understatement).

490137176556404EB983770D90DAEC0F.description: Analyze how an author's choices concerning how to structure specific parts of a text (e.g., the choice of where to begin or end a story, the choice to provide a comedic or tragic resolution) contribute to its overall structure and meaning as well as its aesthetic impact.

FA7386A9BD89462EA32A6888C4708734.description: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in the text, including figurative and connotative meanings; analyze the impact of specific word choices on meaning and tone, including words with multiple meanings or language that is particularly fresh, engaging, or beautiful. (Include Shakespeare as well as other authors.) (See grade 11–12 Language standards 4–6 for additional expectations.)

11C4C78866914E948E8C359EC6F56507.description: Analyze the impact of the author's choices regarding how to develop and relate elements of a story or drama (e.g., where a story is set, how the action is ordered, how the characters/archetypes are introduced and developed).

5034122F531B42ECA362C344518150E3.description: Determine two or more themes or central ideas of a text and analyze their development over the course of the text, including how they interact and build on one another to produce a complex account; provide an objective summary of the text.

C9947262A606414687599067021024EE.description: Cite strong and thorough textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text, including determining where the text leaves matters uncertain.

F3709C42D34646AD965F691AB82C8D02.description: Read and comprehend complex literary and informational texts independently and proficiently.

89F755F2742A4AC097A6FA41736AB35F.description: Range of Reading and Level of Text Complexity

BF6BDDA6C99440BA930C64C672631372.description: Analyze how two or more texts address similar themes or topics in order to build knowledge or to compare the approaches the authors take.

D6C619214F0A4972B8324EE35BD90ABD.description: Delineate and evaluate the argument and specific claims in a text, including the validity of the reasoning as well as the relevance and sufficiency of the evidence.

7157E121A733424C8A61B7B2949C9AD6.description: Integrate and evaluate content presented in diverse media and formats, including visually and quantitatively, as well as in words.
comments: Please see "Research to Build and Present Knowledge" in Writing and "Comprehension and Collaboration" in Speaking and Listening for additional standards relevant to gathering, assessing, and applying information from print and digital sources.

1A7D77B156384B4C9DC9D27BFD6020D1.description: Assess how point of view or purpose shapes the content and style of a text.

8287F2D401BF4CE8A1DDC700BE4CA09B.description: Analyze the structure of texts, including how specific sentences, paragraphs, and larger portions of the text (e.g., a section, chapter, scene, or stanza) relate to each other and the whole.

580E9B061C624F9EA417AE3863E13FE6.description: Interpret words and phrases as they are used in a text, including determining technical, connotative, and figurative meanings, and analyze how specific word choices shape meaning or tone.

F28A4006067C49D1908F7226E16EC314.description: Analyze how and why individuals, events, and ideas develop and interact over the course of a text.

E32F25CE7ED242A3AD449D093066052E.description: Determine central ideas or themes of a text and analyze their development; summarize the key supporting details and ideas.

A9E222494F0E492184DD8A76DC2BC6F5.description: Read closely to determine what the text says explicitly and to make logical inferences from it; cite specific textual evidence when writing or speaking to support conclusions drawn from the text.

634E4635741949FF8C9A04B504C5915D.description: College and Career Readiness Anchor Standards for Reading
